Particularly when it comes to treatment for gender dysphoric youth it's clear that Finland's approach is years of therapy with medical transition, if it's ever offered which I've seen no evidence that it is, as an absolute last resort.

Almost by accident I've found myself doing some very deep investigative reporting on transgender medical care in Finland. I've found about what I expected, but still the gall of some of the Finnish researchers presenting their treatment as analogous to treatment in the US takes my breath away.

This is exactly the approach that opponents of gender affirming care say they want? But Finland research claims their poor results cast doubt on the good outcomes in the US, while completely obscuring what their actual procedures are or how many youth, if any, access hormones or puberty blockers.

The miracle of the oil isn't a distraction from the story of a military victory. It's a reminder that the military victory isn't the point. The miracle isn't a successful rebellion, the miracle is the will to persist against impossible odds. To continue to exist *at all*.

So they add on the story of the miracle of the oil - not as a shiny distraction to make us look away, but as a way to make us refocus on the important part. The part where a tiny remnant of something sacred, almost destroyed by persecuting oppressors, somehow persists.

In that context the story of the Maccabees overcoming the Seleucids sounds more like mockery - "sure, the heroes of old could save the Jews, but you losers are doomed." Which presents a big problem for the early Rabbis, trying to preserve Jewish continuity in the face of tragedy.

It's easy to see how that story might not be such a feel-good blockbuster in the aftermath of not one, not two, but THREE horrifically failed attempts at heroic rebellion, with the Temple not just defiled, but destroyed. In that context it is, in fact, kind of a downer.

The story is, on its face, a celebration of a tiny, fierce band of Jews throwing off an oppressive regime in an act of heroic rebellion and restoring the sanctity of the Temple, refusing to be assimilated.
